metadata.case_name: Kedar Pandey v. Narain Bikram Sah

facts.text: Appellant Kedar Pandey and respondent Narain Bikram Sah (Narain Raja) were contesting candidates in 1962 election to Bihar Legislative Assembly from Ramnagar Constituency on behalf of Congress and Swatantra Party respectively.
Nomination papers of appellant, respondent, Parmeshwar Prasad Roy and Suleman Khan accepted by Returning Officer without objection on January 22, 1962.
Parmeshwar Prasad Roy and Suleman Khan withdrew their candidatures.
After poll, respondent Narain Raja declared elected by majority of valid votes.

Kedar Pandey filed election petition on April 11, 1962 challenging respondent's election, alleging respondent not duly qualified under Art. 173 as not a citizen of India, born in Nepal along with parents and grandparents, related to royal family of Nepal, father owned 43 bighas land and house at Barewa in Nepal in which respondent had share.
Respondent contested petition, claimed Indian citizen, no disqualification under Art. 173, lived in India since birth, resident of Ramnagar in Champaran not Barewa in Nepal, born in Banaras.
Election Tribunal held respondent not citizen of India, not qualified under Art. 173, election void, but refused declaration that Kedar Pandey entitled to be elected.
Both parties appealed to Patna High Court in Election Appeals Nos. 8 and 10 of 1963.

High Court set aside Tribunal's judgment, upheld election, found respondent born in Banaras on October 10, 1918, living in India from 1939 to 1949 and thereafter, acquired domicile of choice in India long before 1949 under Art. 5(a) and (c).
Ramnagar estate originally belonged to Shri Prahlad Sen, passed to Mohan Vikram Sah (Mohan Raja), then Rani Chhatra Kumari Devi (widow), then Rama Raja (father of respondent) after her death in 1937.
Daughter of Prahlad Sen married Birendra Vikram Sah, father of Mohan Raja.
Mohan Raja adopted Rama Raja, executed will in 1904 in favour of wife Rani Chhatra Kumari Devi; Mohan Raja died 1912.
Rani Chhatra Kumari Devi died 1937; Rama Raja took possession of Ramnagar estate from 1937 till death in 1947.

R.S. No. 4 of 1923 by Rani against Rama Raja; T.S. No. 34 of 1924 by Rama Raja against Rani; decided by Additional Sub-Judge Motihari on August 18, 1927 in favour of Rama Raja; High Court dismissed appeal; Privy Council reversed, upheld will, estate not ancestral.
Rama Raja in possession 1927-1931, lost in Privy Council; Rani in possession till 1937.

Partition suit No. 40 of 1942 filed September 29, 1942; preliminary decree April 16, 1943; final decree May 22, 1944; estate divided among Rama Raja and sons including respondent, some properties joint.
Appellant examined Sheonath Tewari (PW 18), N.D. Pathak (PW 15), plaint Ex. 8 mentioning birth at Barewa Durbar.
Respondent examined G.S. Prasad (RW 9) proving birth at Banaras.
Municipal registers of Banaras 1918 (Ex. 2 series) do not mention respondent's birth; explained as house not in municipality limits.
Both High Court and Tribunal found respondent ordinarily resident in India for 5 years preceding commencement of Constitution.
Narain Raja educated in Calcutta 1934-1938; lived in Ramnagar from 1938; continued after father's death 1947; built palace and house in Ramnagar.

After partition 1944, managed joint properties including forests; executed settlements (Ex. X series from 1943, Ex. W 1947, pattas Ex. W/3-5 1945); acquired properties in Champaran, Patna etc. (Ex. F series); owned 500-600 acres.
Indian Passport March 23, 1949 from Lucknow, described as Indian by birth and nationality, address Ramnagar Champaran.
Narain Raja first visited Barewa at 10-12 years old, not for 10 years before 1963.
Married 1950 in Banaras to wife from Darkoti Himachal Pradesh; children born Banaras and Bettiah; daughter studies Dehradun.
Established Prem Janani Sanskrit Vidyalaya in Ramnagar 1950-1951.

Chairman Union Board Ramnagar before Gram Panchayats; Vice-President D.C.M. Union Ramnagar; voter 1952 Ramnagar; candidate 1957 against Kedar Pandey; President Bettiah Sub-divisional Swatantra Party, Vice-President Champaran District Swatantra Party.
Ex. 10(c) khatian 1960 showing 43 bighas land in Nepal in name of Narain Raja and brothers; claimed gifted by grandmother Kanchhi Maiya to Rama Raja (proved by Sanad Ex. AA).
Narain Raja and father used title 'Sri 5' indicating relation to Nepal royal family.
Elder brother Shiv Bikram Sah has male issues.

legal_issues.text: Whether the High Court was right in its conclusion that the respondent Narain Raja was a citizen of India under Art. 5 of the Constitution of India on the material date.
Whether Narain Raja had acquired a domicile of choice in India.

petitioner_arguments.text: High Court not justified in holding Narain Raja born in Banaras 1918; born at Barewa Nepal (witnesses PW18, PW15, Ex.8); municipal registers Ex.2 no entry; litigation history makes PW G.S. Prasad unreliable.
Narain Raja not citizen; owns property in Nepal (Ex.10c); used title 'Sri 5' indicating ties to Nepal royal family.

respondent_arguments.text: Born Banaras (RW9 G.S. Prasad); lived in India since birth, resident Ramnagar; ordinarily resident 5 years pre-Constitution; domicile of choice in India acquired long before 1949.
Domicile of origin from Mohan Raja in India; or acquired by Rama Raja post-1937; or by Narain Raja himself.
Nepal property gifted to father, minor compared to Indian holdings.

court_reasoning.text: Not necessary to decide birthplace as both courts found ordinarily resident in India 5 years pre-Constitution (Art. 5(c) satisfied); appellant did not challenge.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Place of birth loses importance; Art. 5(c) fulfilled.

court_reasoning.text: Assumed domicile of origin Nepal; examined if acquired domicile of choice in India: requires residence + animus manendi (intention of permanent home); onus on those asserting change.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Domicile of origin continues unless clear intention to abandon and acquire new sole domicile.

court_reasoning.text: Facts show long residence in Ramnagar from 1938, management of estate post-1944 partition, property acquisitions, passport 1949 as Indian, political activities, family settlement in India; conduct pre/post 1949 relevant.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Formed deliberate intention of permanent home in India pre-1949.

court_reasoning.text: Nepal property minor, inherited; title 'Sri 5' sentimental, not indicative of domicile intent; no hope of Nepal throne.
Requirements of Art. 5(c) satisfied with domicile in India; citizen at relevant time; qualified under Art. 173.

holdings.text: Narain Raja acquired domicile of choice in India long before end of 1949; ordinarily resident 5 years pre-Constitution; citizen under Art. 5; duly qualified under Art. 173.

precedents_cited.relevance: Domicile of origin continues unless fixed intention to abandon and acquire another shown.
Domicile of origin prevails until manifested intention of abandoning and acquiring sole new domicile (animo et facto).
Mere intention to return on remote contingency does not prevent acquisition of new domicile if settled in foreign country for permanent pursuit.
Principle of intent 'quatenus in illo exuere patriam' misleading; not requiring change of nationality.
Leading authority: Domicile of choice from voluntarily fixing sole/chief residence indefinitely, not temporary; residence freely chosen.
Acquired English domicile shown by marriages, bringing up children, will; vague declarations to return outweighed by facts.

precedents_cited.case_name: In re Grove; Vaucher v. Solicitor to the Treasury
precedents_cited.relevance: Conduct before, at, and after relevant time admissible to determine intention.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Art. 173: Qualification for membership; Art. 5: Citizenship for those domiciled in India and ordinarily resident 5 years pre-Constitution.

outcome.summary: Supreme Court dismissed the appeals, upheld Patna High Court judgment setting aside Tribunal's decision, declared respondent Narain Raja a citizen of India under Art. 5, duly qualified under Art. 173, and his election valid; election petition dismissed.

key_quotes.text: The main question arising for decision in this case is whether the High Court was right in its conclusion that the respondent-Narain Raja--was a citizen of India under Art. 5 of the Constitution of India on the material date.
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: We are of the view that the only intention required for a proof of a change of domicil is an intention of permanent residence.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: States the test for domicile of choice.

key_quotes.text: Taking all the events and circumstances of Narain Rajas life into account we are satisfied that long before the end of 1949 which is the material time under Art. 5 of the Constitution, Narain Raja had acquired a domicil of choice in India.
key_quotes.speaker: court
